data.title: Add support for rebinding Column Selection
data.body:
Currently there is no way to rebind column selection. The only bindings that can be changed for column selection are as follows:
![](http://puu.sh/pVyet/447aaf5f64.png)

 In other programs it's bound by default to `middle click` or `alt+drag`, but in VSCode it's bound to `alt+shift`. It's not an inherently bad thing to do bindings different than other programs, but it'd be nice if it was configurable. I'd really like to change it to `alt`, personally. [And I'm not alone, either.](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1515#issuecomment-224232517)

It's possible that it can already be rebound, but as it's not in the `Default Keyboard Shortcuts` file, there's no way for the basic user to find out that it can be rebound. This would be an even easier fix if that was the case, tho--simply add an entry for it.

data.title: How to open new tab with some formatted text from the extension API
data.body:
Hi , 
I dont find any simple example to open new text document and write some formatted text in it using Visual Studio Code API.

Please provide a small example where i can insert text.
I need it for "visual studio code Settings Sync" Extension

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0 stable ( https://code.visualstudio.com/docs?dv=winzip )
- OS Version:Windows Server 2012 R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. run "E:\Program Files\VSCode\Code.exe" --user-data-dir="E:\Backup\VSCODE" --extensionHomePath="E:\Backup\VSCODE\extensions"
2. then "Extension host terminated unexpectedly. Please reload the window to recover."
3. reload but "Extension host terminated unexpectedly. Please reload the window to recover." again.
4. repeat

data.title: Maximize current editor group (or temporarily hide other editor groups)
data.body:
It would be great if there was a way to quickly hide other editor groups to focus on a single editor (or editor group) without actually closing all the other files. A common workflow for me is to flip between having multiple files open side by side, and having just the currently focused file shown, which is pretty painful to do now.

This is akin to the zen mode or no-distraction mode you see in other software. https://packagecontrol.io/packages/MaxPane also implements this for Sublime.

data.title: [i18n] Incorrect French localization for "rename symbol"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3

Should be "Renommer le symbole":

```

```

File is marked as autogenerated, hence I didn't bother making a pull request.

data.title: Closing a dirty split editor (existing OR untitled) should not affect the initial editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open (or create) a file.
2. Split the editor.
3. Add some text in either editor.
4. Close either editor.
5. Select "Don't save" when prompted.

There are two end states produced by these steps:
#### When an existing file is used

The other editor remains, but the text is reverted to the state on disc.
#### When a file is created

The other editor is also closed.

data.title: Variable Substitution Relative Path
data.body:
adding 'relFile' to support substituting the path to the current open file realtive to cwd

Issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7000

data.title: Fixes #7301: Set LANG for terminal process
data.body:
Setting LANG for the terminal process fixes it. This is also useful when running Cygwin under Windows, so I'm not checking for the platform.

Computing the LANG value could be improved by getting all available values from 'locale -a', but would also make the fix much more involved.

data.title: Command variables in debug adapter freeze VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0 and insiders 4c0676ab472a9
- OS Version: Windows 10

I was trying out the feature [Debug Extension Authoring: Command Variables](https://code.visualstudio.com/Updates#_extension-authoring) for the Microsoft C++ extension.

Back when command variables [were introduced in master](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6569#issuecomment-222913734), it worked fine. However, now that 1.3.0 has been released, I tried again and on Windows the whole editor freezes for about 10 seconds when triggering the command that shows the list of processes as a quick pick dropdown.

I reproed this on my main Windows box, however it doesn't repro on a secondary box I have. I'm not restarting my main box in case you guys need the repro machine.

I took a CPU profile but it just shows `(program)` where it spent most of the time. From what I read online, that's just the actual Chromium code:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/16703448/7668aaf4-4522-11e6-8e00-1ebf1dcb737d.png)

I also didn't really see much in the "Timeline" tab for the dev tools.

Also note that CPU usage for a VSCode process goes up:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/16703922/76129b60-4526-11e6-9efb-5ac9c46029d1.png)

Let me know if you need the profiling dump and I can share it with you internally.

Mentioning @isidorn since he implemented command variables afaik.

data.title: Weird scrollbar behavior
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Win 7 x64 SP1

As soon as the the file being edited has more than one line, the vertical scrollbar appears even though it's not needed.
It seems that the end position of the scrollbars aligns with the last line of the file being the only one visible.

Is this the expected behavior? I don't remember being it this way in 1.2.0 and I don't think any other editor behaves like this.

![animation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412489/16703754/9684be4e-4546-11e6-8fa3-21277c901891.gif)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412489/16703583/30703274-4545-11e6-95d3-aced827ad22f.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412489/16703573/1d713bfa-4545-11e6-9289-487fd3cd30a4.png)

data.title: JS highlighting in certain situations involving strings and HTML tags is incorrect.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (4c0676ab472a92f5269ac4995cdc81db8bc94896, 2016-07-08T15:19:23.853Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14372

Steps to Reproduce:
- Open VS Code to a JS file
- Paste this snippet of code:

``` js
var [] = 'fafa'.replace('blah');
console.log('hello');
```
- Observe the incorrect syntax highlighting following `var [] = '`

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16702767/14f473a2-451d-11e6-9697-a204b3373be6.png)
- Also change the contents of the string at the end of the line to include angle brackets (like an HTML tag):

``` js
var [] = 'fafa'.replace('<blah>');
console.log('hello');
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16702817/66e81ccc-451d-11e6-8afb-beafd9274dcd.png)
- Also note highlighting of keywords inside and outside of braces:

``` js
var [] = 'fafa'.replace('<blah>');
console.log('hello');
while { while() {} }
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16702849/8fde68d4-451d-11e6-96d6-fb2ee2009f51.png)

Originally observed in this snippet of code:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16702633/2fa6a36a-451c-11e6-85c5-c7a8709f8898.png)

Is also an issue with double-quotes `"` instead of single quotes `'` and with or without semicolons.

Not running with any plugins. `code-insiders --disable-extensions`.

1. Open VSCode
2. Minimize it
3. Open another file from any file manager, for example by pressing F4 in Total Commander (where VSCode is set as default editor)

data.title: PowerShell parsing doesn't understand referencing properties by using quotes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.0 (e724f269ded347b49fcf1657fc576399354e6703, 2016-07-07T16:56:12.476Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14372

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a new tab
2. Change the language mode to PowerShell
3. Paste in this text:
   Write-Host -Object 'Looks good'; 
   $xml = [xml]'<root><dash-it-all>text</dash-it-all></root>'; 
   $xml.root.'dash-it-all'; 
   Write-Host -Object 'Looks bad'

Expected: Syntax parsing continues to work
Actual: Most things are now being treated as a string after the $x.'something-something' line

This impacts any referencing of properties where you need to use quotes which is pretty common for XML or JSON references.

data.title: Integrated Terminal fails on Bash on Ubuntu on Windows (pre-release)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (4c0676ab472a92f5269ac4995cdc81db8bc94896, 2016-07-08T15:19:23.853Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14371

I mainly wanted to get this documented, this may not be a supported scenario, but it is one I would like to request as an enhancement if its not.  I understand that Bash on Windows is pre-release.  Not expecting miracles, just wanted to get it on your radar.  This requires a machine in the Windows Insider program to test.
#### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the integrated terminal
2. Type "bash"
3. Type "1234567890"
4. Hit backspace 10 times
#### Expected Results:

All characters are deleted
#### Actual Results

All characters are not deleted, and cursor sometimes "jumps around" on the line being deleted.

data.title: Mismatched colors on retina display vs thunderbolt display

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce: Have a document open, move it from a retina display to a thunderbolt display

The colors don't match when I move the editor from my laptops retina display to a thunderbolt display. I'm guessing it's due to electron, since the same issue is seen here

https://discuss.atom.io/t/text-color-different-on-retina-vs-thunderbolt-display/9451/12

What I can't seem to do is make the same webkit changes. So this is either a bug in electron, or a bug in VScode so I can't add those options.

data.title: Visual studio adding extra spaces on function shorthands
Add key binding condition - terminalFocus
data.body:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but there doesn't seem to be a key binding condition for when the terminal is focused.

This makes commands like `workbench.action.terminal.focusNext` useless as you have to use the mouse to focus the editor.. defeating the purpose of the key binding in the first place.

Something along the lines of `terminalFocus` would be awesome.
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: OSX
